posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: Our team has faced challenges with teaching over the years, particularly after shifting to Python. We’ve been struggling to improve our teaching methods without a software mentor, though any assistance would be greatly appreciated.

There is definitely a steep learning curve for coding especially for beginners. It can be really hard to teach people if they aren't committed. Learning the programming language can be done with plenty of resources and YouTube tutorials but robot code is the challenging part. The best way I learnt this is just by getting a lot of experience with trial and error. And that's one thing we plan to include for our following year: giving the new students projects to do and trying to get them to solve it on their own. Projects like purposely adding bugs in the code and having the students try to figure out the solution. Our team has 2 programming mentors but you guys could definitely do this on your own. Another thing we are doing this year to help keep things organized is creating a document with a step by step instructions for learning something like 1. Learn Python basics 2. Learn OOP with Python 3. Learn robot components etc. This gives a clear way for you to keep track of what stage students are and help students know what they could do to learn if they wish to learn on their own.

posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked: Genuinely wondering, why did you decide to switch to Python? And did you switch from Java or another language?

Python is far superior to Java for developing constrained-time robotics programs in FIRST Robotics Competition. Python's dynamic typing and simplicity significantly reduce development time compared to Java's verbose syntax and rigid structure. Additionally, Python's integration with C libraries via Robotpy enhances performance, making it ideal for competitive robotics. Dynamic typing offers flexibility, avoiding many pitfalls associated with strict typing in languages like Java. Furthermore, Python's superior package management systems, such as pip and virtual environments, streamline installation and updates, reducing setup time. The command-line REPL in Python accelerates testing and debugging, fostering efficiency. Beyond robotics, Python's versatility extends to data science, where ease of use in data visualization sets it apart from Java. This discussion underscores Python's suitability for modern FRC challenges, recognizing Java's value without compromising its applicability elsewhere.

posts.name: Julius
posts.cooked:
Our team lacks software mentors, including previously. Here's our strategy:

Unfortunately, there must be someone to handle the workload independently, learning on their own without assistance, and create a curriculum starting from basic variable creation to integrating the final code into the electronics. Regrettably, that role falls to me due to our limited team size—no other options were available given our schedule constraints.

In my view, a structured lesson or curriculum plan isn't more effective than manual setup. However, that's the only feasible option given our program's limitations.

We utilize Java, so I'm unable to provide a curriculum. Best wishes!

posts.name: Ethan
posts.cooked: While recognizing time constraints related to coding and comparing Python’s compile time and steep learning curve, I firmly believe Java remains significantly more supported than Python. Many vendor libraries aren’t supported in Python, and WPIlib isn’t fully integrated into Python yet. Despite these challenges, however, Java holds greater value in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) due to its robust support, even though it presents compile-time and learning-curve challenges.

posts.name: Ethan
posts.cooked: This year, we focused more on the new programmers in our department than we did previously. I developed a slideshow that thoroughly explains Java’s inner workings in an engaging way. Additionally, I suggested creating a quiz or test to help new students learn through hands-on projects. Regardless of the teaching method, I strongly recommend assigning personal programming projects to students to help them develop their coding skills, research abilities, and troubleshooting techniques.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: I’ve got a quick question for this thread: If you had to quantify the percentage of your time for teaching the core of the language (functions, conditionals, etc) instead of WPILib code (commands, subsystems, etc), what would that number look like (and any have you found success with that strategy)? If you spend a lot of time teaching the language, what robot-specific code do you spend less time on or omit altogether? Conversely, if you spend a lot of time focusing on WPILib and the more niche genre of hardware programming, what language features (if any) do you omit? I imagine that this is very heavily dependent on the previous knowledge of students, so let’s say this question refers to brand-new programmers.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: performance time really isn’t as big a deal as people make it out to be. Disagree. Our team has been trying to get vision systems to work for a while now, and we are switching from python to java this year because auto align will not work as well as we want it to because python is too slow. I agree with the rest of your post though, and python is better in many ways than java for frc. But for using complex vision systems and auto alignment, python simply cannot keep up.

posts.name: Yehudan Rothstein
posts.cooked:
Teaching code effectively, especially to get newcomers comfortable writing subsystem code over a span of 3–4 months, can be quite a challenge. My experience has shown that the most successful methods revolve around two core principles.  

Firstly, allowing novices to encounter and resolve issues independently—as individuals or in small teams—helps build their confidence and problem-solving abilities. Second, setting clear, achievable goals, either through structured projects or targeted reviews of learning resources, provides a solid foundation for progress and keeps them focused on mastering the subject matter. personally, I discovered that observation and interaction with experienced coders were invaluable, though hands-on practice remains crucial.

Our off-season training time is less than that of other teams, so we strongly advise our new students to learn a language independently outside of class. Instead of spending hours giving lectures on programming languages, which students can often learn on their own, we prioritize hands-on experience. For instance, while I only had a basic understanding of Python and had never explored object-oriented programming before, gaining practical experience with robot code was sufficient to teach me everything I know about the subject. Additionally, occasional Google searches helped expand my knowledge further, and similarly, learning Java was streamlined through examining others' code.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
The text is:

sounds like this ship has sailed but … while Python is indeed slow in some ways, “too slow for vision” seems not true? are you trying to run everything on the RoboRio?

**Step-by-step explanation:** 1. **Remove the HTML tag:** Strip away the `

` tags from the beginning and end of the text. 2. **Correct minor language issues:** Rephrase "sounds like this ship has sailed but…" to "this ship has already sailed," improving flow. 3. **Simplify sentence structure:** Change "are you trying to run everything on the RoboRio?" to "do you think everyone’s running on the RoboRio?" for conciseness. 4. **Ensure clarity and grammar:** Make sure the text reads smoothly and maintains its original meaning with minimal changes.

That’s definitely a valid point. Not having access to stuff like advantage kit and other Java tools is a big drawback. But looking back at our season I don’t think there’s ever really been a point where that ever held us back competitively. On the contrary I think the benefits that python brings helped us a lot this year (captaining an alliance at worlds isn’t too bad for our first year)  

But as with everything in life. There’s pros and cons to each language and it’s really up to the individual team to determine which language is more valuable for them.
"so inspiring"

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: Arguably, we have JAVA in classes. We still face issues with obtaining coders. We’ve sent students to Kettering annually over the past few summers. Though it’s not practical, however, we’ve been doing it for several years. It remains not ideal, financially infeasible, or cost-effective.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: We use limelight, and vision works, however, Python isn't fast enough for the more complex tasks we aim to perform, such as full auto alignment. Using Python with vision this year didn't meet our requirements, though Python generally functions well. There comes a point where its capabilities start to constrain robot performance, necessitating a switch to Java when needed.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Yeah, you have to make your own choices, but honestly, I think you might not know what's causing the issue.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
If your team can achieve it, I would suggest your veteran students establish an explicit goal to concentrate away from coding and more towards documenting, process establishing, and training. By focusing on these areas, your team can enhance their mentorship capabilities while improving the technical skills of others. The trade-off involves investing time in soft skills and effective communication strategies, which are highly beneficial in the long run.  

A local team, SteelRidge, demonstrated the effectiveness of not having a dedicated code mentor over many years, allowing their students to build curriculum and train additional students. Their success inspired our team to completely rework our processes to adopt their innovative ideas. Engaging with other local teams and incorporating their practices is not just feasible but likely advantageous, as they are willing to share their methods.  

Our curriculum and documentation aim to bridge the gap for students starting from scratch, guiding them efficiently from foundational knowledge to proficient coding abilities without getting bogged down by unrelated concepts. The WPILib documentation serves as a standout resource but presents a significant hurdle due to its complexity. By adapting the minimalist approach from SteelRidge, we create a structured curriculum with clear documentation tailored to students' varying levels of expertise. This system allows flexibility, enabling students to progress at their own pace while ensuring comprehensive understanding.

That’s interesting. We also used vision with limelights and achieved automatic alignment. We just used PID control to auto-align, so what is your team using for full auto alignment that cannot be performed with Python?

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: Thank you all for the ideas. I will definitely use this to help me. Also, I'm the only person on my team who knows software, but all the advice is very nice to have, thank you.
